Name: International Trade
Description: Census International Trade data is accessible through the U.S. Census Bureau's main Foreign Trade portal (https://www.census.gov/foreign-trade/). For NAICS-specific trade information, users can access the NAICS Index (https://www.census.gov/foreign-trade/statistics/country/naics/index.html) or use USA Trade Online for detailed NAICS data (https://usatrade.census.gov/). Documentation on methodology is available through the International Trade Statistical Program description (https://www.census.gov/foreign-trade/guide/sec2.html), International Trade Definitions (https://www.census.gov/foreign-trade/reference/definitions/index.html), and the Guide to International Trade Datasets (https://www.census.gov/foreign-trade/reference/guides/Guide_to_International_Trade_Datasets.pdf). Developers can utilize the International Trade API (https://www.census.gov/data/developers/data-sets/international-trade.html) to access Monthly U.S. Exports and Imports by NAICS classification.

Name: Production and Capacity
Description: For comprehensive information about the G.17 Industrial Production dataset, you can access the main G.17 page (https://www.federalreserve.gov/releases/g17/) which serves as the top-level menu. For citation documentation and detailed information, refer to the explanatory notes (https://www.federalreserve.gov/releases/g17/About.htm), the Data Download Program (https://www.federalreserve.gov/datadownload/Choose.aspx?rel=g17), and the FRED page with citation format (https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/INDPRO). Technical documentation is available through resources on industrial production methodology (https://www.federalreserve.gov/releases/g17/IpNotes.htm), capacity utilization methodology (https://www.federalreserve.gov/releases/g17/CapNotes.htm), and source and description tables (https://www.federalreserve.gov/releases/g17/SandDesc/sdtab1.pdf).

Name: Price Indices
Description: The Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) produces a complementary set of key economic indicators through its Producer Price Index (PPI) and International Price Program (IPP) which includes both Import and Export Price Indices. These three major price indices work together to provide a comprehensive view of price movements throughout the U.S. economy and its international trade relationships. The PPI measures price changes from domestic producers' perspective (https://www.bls.gov/ppi/), tracking inflation pressures before they reach the consumer level, while the Import and Export Price Indices track price changes in goods and services traded between the U.S. and foreign countries (https://www.bls.gov/mxp/). All three indices share similar methodological foundations—using representative baskets of goods and services, matched-item pricing, and detailed classification systems—but focus on different economic domains. Together, they serve critical functions in economic analysis: deflating components of GDP, adjusting contracts for inflation, measuring terms of trade, analyzing exchange rate effects, assessing industrial competitiveness, and providing early signals of inflation trends. Users can access detailed methodology documentation (https://www.bls.gov/ppi/methodology-reports/methodology.htm and https://www.bls.gov/opub/hom/ipp/concepts.htm), download customized datasets (https://www.bls.gov/ppi/databases/ and https://www.bls.gov/mxp/data/), and view the latest releases and analyses through the BLS website, making these indices essential tools for economists, policymakers, and business analysts seeking to understand price dynamics across domestic and international markets.

Name: Current Employment Statistics
Description: For comprehensive access to the Current Employment Statistics (CES) dataset, users can explore the main CES program page (https://www.bls.gov/ces/) and the dedicated CES data portal (https://www.bls.gov/ces/data/). Detailed methodological information is available in the BLS Handbook of Methods (https://www.bls.gov/opub/hom/ces/) with specific concepts explained in the concepts documentation (https://www.bls.gov/opub/hom/ces/concepts.htm). Technical aspects of the survey and benchmarking procedures are covered in the technical notes (https://www.bls.gov/web/empsit/cestn.htm). Researchers requiring data extraction can utilize the various data access tools (https://www.bls.gov/ces/data/home.htm), while answers to common technical questions can be found in the FAQ section (https://www.bls.gov/web/empsit/cesfaq.htm). Monthly releases and analytical publications are available through the publications page (https://www.bls.gov/ces/publications/), providing the most current economic indicators derived from this survey.

Name: M3 Manufacturers Shipments, Inventories & Orders
Description: For comprehensive information on the Census M3 Manufacturers' Survey, visit the main M3 page (https://www.census.gov/manufacturing/m3/index.html) where you can access detailed documentation including survey methodology (https://www.census.gov/manufacturing/m3/about_the_surveys/index.html), key definitions (https://www.census.gov/manufacturing/m3/definitions/index.html), and data collection procedures (https://www.census.gov/manufacturing/m3/how_the_data_are_collected/index.html). The FRED database (https://fred.stlouisfed.org/release?rid=95) provides formatted data series with standard citation formats. For the most current data, refer to the Monthly Advance Report (https://www.census.gov/manufacturing/m3/adv/current/index.html) and Monthly Full Report (https://www.census.gov/manufacturing/m3/current/index.html). The survey is conducted under the authority of Title 13 United States Code, Sections 131, 182, and 193.

Name: Investment
Description: The Bureau of Economic Analysis provides comprehensive access to National Income and Product Accounts through its main NIPA tables page (https://www.bea.gov/itable/national-gdp-and-personal-income) and Interactive Data Application (https://apps.bea.gov/iTable/?reqid=19). For more detailed investment data, researchers can access the Underlying Detail Tables page (https://apps.bea.gov/iTable/?reqid=19&step=2&isuri=1&categories=underlying) or the machine-readable quarterly data text file that you referenced (https://apps.bea.gov/national/Release/TXT/NipaDataQ.txt). To understand the methodology behind these statistics, the NIPA Handbook (https://www.bea.gov/resources/methodologies/nipa-handbook) offers comprehensive documentation, with Chapter 6 specifically detailing Private Fixed Investment concepts and methods (https://www.bea.gov/resources/methodologies/nipa-handbook/pdf/chapter-06.pdf). When citing BEA data in technical documentation, researchers should follow the official Guidelines for Citing BEA (https://www.bea.gov/help/guidelines-for-citing-bea) to ensure proper attribution of these valuable economic indicators.
